title: Deep Thought
description:
This week has been a little short on time, so I haven't been able to spend as much time on the project as I want to, but it does force me to  think about time as a design constraint, particularly for implementing these activities in classrooms. I got the MVP (minimum viable project) working, and then I thought...what else do I have time for? In <30 minutes, there's definitely not enough time for looking for/making sprites, so I stuck with what was in the sprite library. And, it's a reminder that the sprite library is so rich! And I still have a fully functioning project!

If I had more time, I would make the answers more respondent to the questions, instead of just at random. Any thoughts on how to do that much appreciated!

Music: Zora's Domain (night) - Zelda breath of the wild.
instructions: Press the green flag to start, and follow along! Hitchhiker's inspired.

title: Magic Marble Therapy
description: I was scared of this project because I didnt' know how to do it! But then I realized how the list function works and I used that!! It was exciting.

title: Answer
description:
This project was created for Day 16 of Getting Unstuck. I was really vexed by today's challenge -- so many possible ways to explore the idea of answering someone's question! In the end, I channeled advice from @karenb on Day 13 to "try to reconnect with your loves and see where they take you."

Sounds are from freesound.org; graphics are from pixabay.com.
instructions:
Press the green flag to have your question answered.

(Best enjoyed in full-screen mode.)

title: 5-Question Scratch Cat Jeopardy
description:
(For Day 16 of Getting Unstuck)
Today's invitation to make was: "Create a program that answers the user's questions." My first thought was to create a Magic 8 ball, but then I tried to think of other situations where the user (or the player) is stating a question. I was reminded of someone from our apartment building who watches Jeopardy in one of the building's common areas every evening and used that as my inspiration. I took the questions from Jeopardy's online practice test sets (Teen edition).
Were I to invest more time in this project, I would...
* make it a big more flexible for answers that are "close enough"
* make it more Jeopardy-like, with identified categories and varying prize amounts
instructions: Press the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 16: Foodie dice!
description:
I was stuck on this challenge. The only thing I could think of that directly answered the prompt was some sort of magic 8 ball... which is cool, but not what I wanted to make! Eventually, with the help of @paulinah, I remembered a great gift I received for Christmas—foodie dice! They're meant to help you decide what to eat. So, I decided to turn this into my project :)

It's not exactly answering a question the user *poses*, but I think it's definitely a question lots of people have!

I'd like to come back to this later and add in more options, store the options in a list, and then only show the options available for those conditions.

Wood image from Wikimedia Commons.
Foodie dice found here! https://www.foodiedice.com/
instructions: This project answers age-old question... what should I make for dinner tonight?

title: Tell Me More
description:
I got most stuck conceptualizing this project. I had a difficult time thinking about how to frame questions and answers in this context. Initially I wanted to try to really have the answers "make sense", that is, for the project to listen well and respond accordingly. Listening is HARD, and teaching a computer how to listen well seemed too large a hurdle any of the attempts I made at it. 

So, I wondered how I might highlight that dilemma in the answers. I thought some more about listening, to each other and ourselves, and wondered how I might make a list of responses to think with. I ended up searching to see if I could find an interview by teacher + teacher educator Eleanor Duckworth. I thought I'd take the "answers" from there. (I didn't have a particular interview in mind, just that I'd like to to find one.)

I found 'On Thinking about Teaching: A Conversation with Eleanor Duckworth', and pulled out some of her responses and this project unfolded (:
http://www.ascd.org/ascd/pdf/journals/ed_lead/el_199103_meek.pdf

loop that I used:
https://freesound.org/people/arseniiv/sounds/159422/

loops that I thought I might use:
https://freesound.org/people/zagi2/sounds/351433/
https://freesound.org/people/suonho/sounds/57870/
instructions: Press the green flag to start to interact with Truffle (:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 16 - The ChatDuck5000
description:
This project uses the stringToWords block by @jsh from his Visual Editor of a few days ago: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236732850/ Thanks! 
HINT - you don't have to remix to reuse - the backpack will carry items between projects if you're working online (look at the bottom of the editor). Remember to credit those who help you. 

The duck splits the words of the question and uses the first word - probably the question word. It looks in a list Q for this word and if it's there it uses a corresponding reply. With more time I would extend the code to check the whole sentence to allow it to scan for trigger words like Orange or Quack and create a response. 

You can see the lists used Q and A - dive in and remix to add some more replies. The trigger word (if first word in the question) will result in the reply. The last entry in A is the response if no match is found and should always be the last item.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 16

Click the green flag. Ask your questions of the great duck, o mortal.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 16 — Magic Advice
description:
Reflection

This is a straight up recreation of a Magic 8-ball. The user asks a question and then a random answer is selected from a dataset of answers stored in a list. The part that took the longest was manually inserting the answers into the list. This probably took me about 15 minutes to complete.

Here's a Wikipedia article on the Magic 8-Ball:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_8-Ball
instructions: Ask Scratchy a yes or no question.

title: Getting Unstuck #16
description:
This was a tricky one, and then I thought about who is best at seeming to answer questions without actually doing so, and after that it was easy. The tricky thing was deciding on which politicians to choose.

I've updated this so that if you ask someone the same question twice she or he gives an appropriate response.

title: Getting Unstuck day 16
description:
I took today as an opportunity to revisit and improve an old project. A number of people have mentioned doing so the last couple of weeks and I have been meaning to follow their lead. This is a fairly straightforward magic 8 ball type project. I removed the extraneous code that recreated the list of answers every time the program is run. I also made it possible to ask another question without enduring the set up spiel each time. Finally, I added a spooky soundtrack of radio noise recorded by NASA's Cassini spacecraft (RIP brave robot). 

soundtrack - https://soundcloud.com/nasa/cassini-saturn-radio-emissions-2?in=nasa/sets/spookyspacesounds

title: Getting Unstuck #16: Internet Safety Quiz
description:
In fact, the user answers the program's questions and the program evaluates their responses and calculates the user's score.

Originally, I created this Scratch project as part of a lesson plan for the WWW2 handbook (http://webwewant.eu/handbookdownload/handbook/). The Quiz aims to raise pupils' awareness on Internet safety issues.

Special thanks to Scratch wiki editors for providing useful quiz implementation tips here http://wiki.scratch.mit.edu/wiki/Creating_a_Quiz

Instrumental music by Longzijun

Day #16 Challenge of "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education: Create a program that answers the user's questions.
instructions: Press the Green Flag and then, the Space key to take the quiz.

title: Day 16:  Ask the Squirrel
description:
Like many, I struggled with how I can make the conversation seem authentic.  So I decided that I could at least code it so in the beginning when the squirrel ask the user a question that it recognizes if the input is correct or not and responds accordingly.  After that, I had to go for more generic answers.  Actually, they are the 10 ten ways to avoid answering a question.    
I just thought of an additional idea that I would like to include in this project.  That is to use the the list block: CONTAIN THING?  I hope to get back to this project later today to add that option as well.  With this, I think I can answer the where, what, who, why and when questions that may give the user the feeling that the squirrel really is understanding their questions. 
 
Nature sounds from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKnS8VPxpHI
instructions:
Day 16 Challenge: Create a program that answers the user's questions.

Press the green flag to talk to the squirrel.  He will answer any question you may have!  Sometimes he gets a little grumpy if you don't answer his questions correctly!  Many find him a bit evasive!

title: Snake chatbot (Getting Unstuck Day 16)
description:
I made this project for Getting Unstuck Day 16. It's my fourth Unstuck project (one is my other account: @PinkyPepper). Wow, I am amazed by how many people already made 16 projects. Good job!

I've wanted to make a chatbox for a long time, but never took the time to actually do it. Now I did :) I've used this tutorial made by @crazynimbus: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/23615814/ The hardest part is making interesting questions. I'll try to add some more later on.

The drawings of the snake are inspired by a childrens book of Catharina Valckx, called "Poten omhoog!" ("Hands up"). I've made them three years ago for this project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/61060236/

Thanks to @DeKrache for the stars used in this project.
instructions:
PLEASE CLICK ON THE SNAKE TO CHAT.

You may just say "Hello" and/or ask one of the following questions:
- What is your name?
- What time is it?
- Do you like Scratch?
- What is your favorite food?
- What's your favorite colour?
- How old are you?

Or you could just ask a random question...

Getting Unstuck: Day 16

This is not the project I wanted to do. I wanted to use a list for questions and possibly a list for answers, but I have not been able to. I still do not know how to use the lists ...
instructions: Click on green flag to start.

title: Unstuck 16 Ask me a math question
description:
Wow, this became very difficult for me very quickly.
My code tried to determine if a valid math problem has been entered, and then solves it. It has to find a number followed by an operator (+ - * /) followed by a number, then calculate the answer.
I didn't have enough time and would still like to put in more error checking:
-more than one operator entered
-divide by zero
-invalid number format either before or after the operator
I also wondered about a way to display the calculated answer in a larger more celebratory format, like as a sprite that could be animated. I will look into that. As I'm learning more about scratch, I wish it had some features of other languages, like a function that returns a value.

-non-numeric characters entered
instructions: Create a program that answers the user's questions.

That's when I thought of using a forgetful granny. I used a Google image that was labeled for reuse from Public Domain pictures.
instructions: Press the flag. Granny will introduce herself then prompt you to ask questions.

title: geo quiz
description:
Today I'm in a super-rush... no eye candies!

Just two thoughts:
1) If you need a non-dynamic two-dimensional array, just use two lists with the same index.
2) Did you know that you can import list from a text file? Every line is a record. Just right-click on the list and select "import" (you can export, too).

The map is from Wikipedia by Strebe
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_map#/media/File:Winkel_triple_projection_SW.jpg
instructions:
Enter a capital or a country, the cat will find the corresponding country or capital!

The names have to be correct and no acronyms are allowed... so the cat won't find "USA", you should search for "United States of America".
The accented words are made with an apostrophe!

script for typing effect from - https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/115324471 by @footsocktoe

I have been wanting to try the typing effect since @jsh used it a few days ago. I thought today was the day and then I looked at the script! I promise myself I will set aside time to pull it apart and figure it out, but today was, in fact, NOT the day! I found a much simpler substitute from @footsocktoe and used that instead. 
I have lots of practice with the Magic 8 ball (coins, dice, spinners, paper fortune tellers, etc!) as I do a unit with 3rd grade every year on creating Scratch randomizers. I was looking for a slightly different take, just for a change.

Keep up the excellent prompts ScratchEd Team!
instructions: Press the flag and enter your responses in this very brief session of Zork, a classic work of interactive fiction.

title: CSQuiz
description:
The quiz is in the list "data":
1 line - topic of the quiz
2 line - question 1
3 line - 1 answer
4 line - 2 answer
5 line - 3 answer
6 line - 4 answer
7 line - 5 answer
8 line - question 1
9 line - 1 answer
10 line - 2 answer
11 line - 3 answer
12 line - 4 answer
13 line - 5 answer
The last line contains only one character "#"
Each line of answers begins with a "-" symbol if the answer is incorrect, and the "+" symbol if the answer is correct
instructions:
This is the shell for creating quizzes in Scratch.
Press GreenFlag to start.
Choose the right answers by clicking the button next to it - button will change its color to blue.
Then click "check answers" - the correct answers are green, wrong - red.

title: Reader Response_GU_Day16
description:
I noticed that some projects produce nonsensical responses b/c the questions are not tightly enough constrained. I had many ideas today. Here's the rationale for the one I picked: The way “novels are taught” in many classrooms makes me crazy because the joy of reading is sucked away by countless low-level comprehension questions. EQ: How can teachers provide readers with more inspiring questioning?
I am working on a bug. Yesterday I played with @jamesdotca 's Connect the Dots. For some reason, my drawing code is not working yet, even though it looks the same as his. My sprite is having laggy, or no, response. Now I'm trying a work-around. Next, trying to get unstuck about letting the user change the pen color mid-drawing. I have a solution! Play and find out! (Bonus Q: If you cross over a line that you have already drawn, what happens?)
Credits:
http://pngimg.com/download/2115
https://www.flickr.com/photos/dominicspics/8554677475
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Borrtex/Emotion/2Gratitude
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin.
Follow the prompts.
When you have finished drawing, click the stop sign icon. 
Then show someone what you have created!
Follow-up activity: Pretend that you are the character. Write a thank-you note that explains why you are grateful for the gift.

title: Challenge 16 - Scratch Dictionary
description:
Had a bit of trouble thinking of what to do today. Then I thought about a dictionary. Have always wanted to create one. Few things I may do with this. 

May create the backdrops as a webpage search engine etc but we'll see how time goes. 

pathikrit on github created the dictionary file of words, parts of speech and defintions. 

I parsed them to create a csv file to import into the Scratch lists.
instructions:
Created a 6000 word dictionary on Scratch. Type a word to see if it is there. If you can't find a word, click on the word list, it will show you the list to scroll through.

The right margin on the text engine isn't perfect but it will do for this project. That will be a whole new rewrite down the road. 

This showed me I have to work on my vocabulary. 6000 words and he don't know none of me's.

Sorry, this is the only dictionary I could find that I could work with in Python and add to Scratch. Scratch as a 10048 list item limit. BIG WORDS!!!!!!!

instructions: Click the green arrow to begin.

title: Regrouping: Getting Unstuck Day 16 Questions
description:
Getting Unstuck

At the moment, I am only able to count out the tokens required to show the addition, but I can't get them to regroup by 10s properly. For some reason, my "repeat" loop cuts out before looping as many times as I am asking for. I'll have to come back to this one...

If anyone wants to have a look in the "regrouping" event for the ball sprite, I would be much obliged!

OK, I've got the regrouping by 10 happening, but I've since learned that I cannot go above 301 clones of a sprite, so I may have to think on this and come back, at least if I want to multiply large double-digit numbers.

I've also modified my scripts to include an idea coming from other Scratchers... instead of broadcasting and receiving from multiple clones (lots of broadcasting, so causing lots of unintended craziness) I should have one uncloned sprite do the broadcasting (and use "broadcast and wait" as well) and the clones do the receiving. That way, it's easier to control the timing of all clones' movements. It also helps to conceptualize breaking down the project into smaller steps, much like functions might, with each broadcast block dedicated to doing different things.
instructions:
Ask Scratch Cat to do any math operation (add, subtract, divide, and multiply) with numbers up to 99.
He'll give you the answer AND show how it's done.
(For the moment, Scratch Cat only knows whole numbers and can only add numbers up to 99, but other operations will eventually be added!)

title: Cappello magico
instructions: Clicca la bandiera verde e segui le istruzioni

title: Unstuck Day 16/17- Text Input
description:
This was for the Getting Unstuck challenge Day 16 but turned into a big project that I didn't have time to finish in one day. Luckily the next day challenge pretty much fits the bill as well, so it covers Day 17, too!
I have made and taught a hangman game in Python so I thought this would be doable but ran into many many problems. One was not planning carefully enough in the beginning. I was taking out random letters instead of all occurrences of specific letters.
Then Scratch does not have indexed loops (for loops) so I had to make various counters to do things based on the the current loop number. 
I have not used Snap much but this would be a good project for Snap as it would have been useful to have custom blocks that can report something. In Scratch I had to create many variables to keep track of little tasks that would have been easier with reporting blocks.
instructions:
Play Guess the Word! This is for two players, one to type the secret word and the other to guess. Have fun!
If you want to see something cool click "under the hood" while you play and you can see the program processing the tasks as you give it input.
Note: The reason your word can't be a phrase is the program knows when you have guessed the word by checking if it has no more spaces in it, so the spaces would keep you from every being finished.

title: Hanoi Towers
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 16
by Massimo Marletta

The Hanoi Towers Game

The main logic is in the Stack sprite, which handles a list of the sizes of the blocks which are stacked in it. The Block sprite have different costumes to represent different sizes.
An extensive use of broadcast message is used to pass game control from the sprites. Nano is the game controller which send appropriate messages to the sprites. Tera gives instruction to the user.
To satisfy challenge requirement, the user can make moves by answering to Nano's questions.
instructions:
Hanoi towers is a classical game.

(Click on Tera to see game instructions)

You have three stacks and a series of blocks in the first stack.
You can move the top block of one stack to another stack, with the aim to move all the blocks to the stack 3... but you cannot put a block over a smaller one!
There is a famous solution to the game, but this project is not about computer giving the solution: it is up to you to move all the blocks to their destination!

title: UnStuck Day 16

title: Getting Unstuck 16
description:
Now that I actually interpreted the prompt correctly, this does what it's supposed to do. I loved making these fortune tellers (or cootie catchers, as we called them) when I was a kid.

The "unfolding" animation doesn't look great, but overall I'm happy with it. If I have more time the main thing I'd like to add would be error checking. Right now it just trusts the user to enter the right numbers and colors to make the fortune teller work, but if someone typed in, say, violet instead of purple for the color at the end it won't work.

Cootie Catcher images from https://boingboing.net/2015/08/18/brief-history-of-the-cootie-ca.html

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 16
description:
Thank you to the Facebook Group and mstone326 for giving me the easy way to load lists from CSV files.  So much easier...that's the only reason I chose this project.

I'm sure there is an easier way to choose which letter to highlight.  What I did was extremely repetitive. There's probably a way to use another list and an index.  I would appreciate any advice.

If I were to add to this I would use a Ouji Board pointer to move to each letter before I highlight it and show it.  I'd probably have to move the center for each letter so that the pointer does not obscure the letter.
instructions:

I wanted to make a Magic 8 Ball...but then decided to combine it with a Ouji Board to use more of the string functions.

title: Ask Quelo
description:
The inspiration from this project comes from one of my favorite Italian comedians, Corrado Guzzanti, who played the role of a guru of an invented religion, based on the cult a piece of wood called Quelo.

I've spent most of my time looking at other people's projects and realizing that most of my initial ideas had been realized already. It was hard to get the program respond to different questions, so this character and his jokes came into mind.

I've spent a bit of time thinking whether or not to share it.. as the reference might be fully appreciated by people who know the character, but I decided to share it anyway! I have 5 more project to go!

C'è grooossa crisi! :)
instructions:
Ask a deep question to Quelo.

Who are we? Where do we come from? Where do we go?

title: Random Answers (Getting Unstuck #16)
description:
Getting Unstuck activity #16 - "Create a program that answers the user's questions."

Simple script which asks for a questions and then gives a random numerical answer. It does a quick check of question length in order to provide some cheeky reply prior to the answer.

I'm catching up on the final week's worth of activities so this is quick and simple. It could be improved by attempting to parse the question to look for keywords or limit to maths questions which could be parsed and evaluated in script.
instructions: Click the flag and ask some questions.  I doubt you'll get the right answer!
